div.p: Bibliothèque des Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques, Geneva.

The specimens of Meliaceae, honored Sir, sent by me,
See M to C. de Candolle, 24 February 1894. are certainly mostly in a very bad state or imperfect condition, but you must kindly remember that in New Guinea and most parts of Polynesia are as yet no good dwellings and no easily transversable roads, so that in the difficult transit the specimens are apt to suffer. The collectors can also not always from the high trees get flowers and fruits, even if both were obtainable at the same time.

Pray, do not go to any great trouble about this material, as your time is so very valuable; but if you find anything workable among the lot of specimens I shall be delighted if you will elaborate it and publish it there. You need not return much one leflet
leaflet? and one flower or one fruit will even suffice, if not more can be returned.

As regards transit, I find sending of cases very costly, and never forward anything except as to arrive free at its destination. Since the last 3 years, when under the retrenchments during the great finance-depression in this colony, my resources became so very limited I have adopted the plan, to send the specimens for herbariums by post in small lots. It is the safest, the cheapest and the quickest method. Meliaceae are always brittle and will suffer more in the transit than most other plants

If I can manage to send a case or box of specimens, what will be the best way? Is it best to send by the Messageries maritimes to Marseille? or by the German Steamers to Genoa? Have you any of these two places or elsewhere on the mediterranean Sea an Agent? When I come to the Myoporinae I shall have to make up a caise
sic.
for your herbier. We here by incessent Efforts have now gradually learnt the respective geographic distribution of the numerous Eremophilas over the Australian Continent.
I often think of your illustrious father and indeed also Grandfather and indeed also sometimes of your hopeful grandson.
